title: Friday night takeout
text: Time for takeout: Philly Cheese steak Poutine was delicious - flavors were amazing! Also enjoyed their blended crab soup, a combination of New England and Maryland crab soups, one of their specialties.

title: Delicious lunch in St Michaels!
text: Great lunch! My husband had a crab cake sandwich, all crabmeat! I had fried oyster sandwich - wonderful! Oysters were lightly breaded with panko, just right. Great atmosphere along the water.

title: Colonial history in PA
text: We arrived here to see the covered bridge, which is located at the entrance. We had packed our lunch and enjoyed eating at one of their picnic tables. Lovely setting, historic buildings, broom-making, and nice gift shop. It was a nice stop on our way to see all the covered bridges in Bedford County!

title: Beautiful, historic park
text: A park for history enthusiasts, hikers, and runners. This park is a lovely setting to explore. Visit the museum and walk/hike on more than a dozen trails. We came to the park to see the beautiful Knox Covered Bridge. The bridge was originally built in 1851 and spans Valley Creek.

title: Not painted red!
text: Red is the traditional color of covered bridges, but not Hunsecker's Mill Covered Bridge. Built in 1848, this bridge was lifted up off its abutments from rising waters in 1972 and carried downstream! It was rebuilt the next year, with a length of 180 feet. Unique to this bridge are horizontal floor boards - gives a different vibration when crossing! Beautiful setting!

title: Historical Covered Bridge
text: This covered bridge is also known as Eshleman's Mill Covered Bridge or Paradise Bridge. Built in 1845 and rebuilt in 1893, the bridge spans the Pequea Creek in Lancaster County. We spent a day driving through the countryside and enjoyed locating these historical bridges!

title: Shoo-Fly Pie!
text: This is a very noticeable building! Right along the very busy Rt 30. Known for their Shoo-Fly pies for many years, the pie can also be bought by the slice - and it is delicious! When you enter, you are in a gift shop. There are some wood pieces of small furniture items, lots of very touristy items, and the baked goods. The reason to stop is the baked goods! If you are not familiar with Shoo-Fly pie, this is typical of the PA Dutch area, made with molasses and lots of brown sugar!

title: Beautiful Setting!
text: This bridge was built in 1891 at a different location. It was dismantled, moved and rebuilt at this present location in 2010. It is next to a beautiful home with a peaceful setting. We so enjoyed driving through the countryside to view these historic bridges!

title: Hidden location
text: First, the picture shown is for another location. I have attached the correct picture. This bridge, although built in the 1800's, had damages from flooding in 1986 and was rebuilt - raising it 4 feet and lengthening 9 feet. We so enjoyed driving through the countryside to find these historic bridges!

title: Love the covered bridge!
text: We came to the park to find the covered bridge. It did not disappoint! The park is quite large and beautiful!

title: Neighborhood Landmark
text: "Little Italy" is one of the nicest areas of Baltimore! There is one wonderful restaurant after another. Chiapparelli's is one of the best! Serving authentic Italian cuisine, they have been in business since 1940.

title: Delicious!
text: It was so nice to go out to a restaurant again! My Lemon Drop martini was made with their own Limoncello, Bruschetta Pomodoro made with fresh locally-grown tomatoes topped with mozzarella filled with ricotta curd, scallops on parmigiana reggiano risotto with lemon cream sauce, sauteed shrimp with house-made linguini and pesto sauce, dessert of orange-ricotta cream and fresh berries. Everything was wonderful!! Great service too!

title: Beautiful gardens
text: What a lovely place to visit with friends and enjoy nature! The Spring flowers were blooming and the sun shining.

title: Nice Picnic Area
text: A couple days ago, met friends for a picnic. This is a large, beautiful park with many pavilions and picnic tables and available parking. There is a fenced area for people to bring their dogs, and a soccer field. A lovely place to go to enjoy being outdoors.

title: Delicious lunch!
text:
I had chicken quesadilla - so good!! It was hot, cheese melted just right, and the caramelized onions were fantastic! Served with guacamole, sour cream and salsa - perfect! My friend had the quiche of the day and crab soup. She loved it! The crab soup is a blend of New England style with Maryland crab soup - unique and delicious (my husband orders it every time he eats here)!

If you like beer, they have a menu just for beer!

Great place, very popular in York! We came early for lunch (11:30), so were able to be seated right away. It's a busy place.

title: Dinner
text:
Wanted a casual dinner, soup and sandwich. I ordered a salmon burger which came with bacon lettuce and tomato, and an aeoli sauce. It was delicious! Their sweet potato fries are amazing - enough for 2 people, though!

Menu has nice selection of items! Decor is comfortable and pleasant. We sat in the restaurant, and the bar area is very popular for seating as well.

title: Good lunch!
text:
Ordered salmon burger - delicious!
Nice selection of sandwiches, burgers, etc.
I was here for dinner in December and had a wonderful pasta meal.
Decor is lovely!

My reason for 4 stars instead of 5 is that the menu tends to have a lot of items that are either spicy or with a cream sauce. I don't want bland food, but would appreciate more of a selection that doesn't include one of the above.

Definitely recommend this restaurant!

title: Best pizza we had in Italy!
text: We took the time to find this place because I had read great reviews - delicious! If you want a table inside, you must tell them when you order. We shared a table with others, one couple from Naples. We had Margherita and loved it! Oh...ask for heart- shaped! It's their special touch!

title: Wonderful lunch
text: French cuisine; interior nicely decorated, like a French bistro. Menu has good variety, including daily soup, quiche and special. I had a delicious salmon burger served with shoe string fries in a wire basket. My friends had the special: ham and cheese crepes with a beautiful side salad. We all enjoyed creme caramel! Highly recommend.

title: Delicious
text: Right on Corso Umberto, this was exactly what I wanted - Granite Limone!! The granite is all the way in the back, and they offer many flavors. My favorite is the lemon, so I was able to enjoy before we left Sicily. Beautiful weather, and we enjoyed sitting at one of the tables outside.

title: Piazza Duomo
text: Quiet Piazza with Cathedral of Taormina, a medieval church known as the "Cathedral fortress", and Quattro Fontane di Taormina.

title: Great stop for lunch
text: Great selection of arancino - I had one with spinach and it was delicious! They are made, so it is a perfect stop if you want to eat on the go or enjoy the outdoor tables.

title: Main street through Taormina
text: Restaurants, shops, and picturesque! You can walk from one gate to the other gate at the end of this thoroughfare, through piazzas, in about 10 minutes - you can decide how much time you want to spend shopping and admiring this beautiful town.

title: Ancient Greek- Roman theater
text: This 3rd century BC Greek theater was carved out of rock. At a later time, the Romans added columns. More views of the sea and My Etna.

title: Piazza with views
text: Following Corso Umberto, you walk through a medieval clock tower into this lovely Piazza! There are 2 churches, Chiesa di Sant' Giuseppe and Chiesa di Sant' Agostino, which has the beautiful checkerboard tiles in front of it. You can see Mt Etna in the distance - the top of the volcano is covered with some white puffy clouds in my picture. October is a great time to travel in this area - temperatures in the 70's! (Farenheit)

title: Enjoyed this castle
text: Constructed early 6th century BC! It is the oldest fortification in Naples. We walked from our ship, lovely walk along the water. It was about 30 minutes from where we were docked. Free admission. We enjoyed exploring this castle! The views of Naples are lovely!

title: Medieval castle
text: We walked from our ship - lots of construction around it. We paid to enter and walked around on our own. We were not interested in an hour guided tour. The upper floors are accessible by an elevator, but found they are mostly displaying art. Spent about half an hour. Worth seeing!

title: Quick ascent to city center of Valletta
text: There were at least 5 cruise ships docked when we arrived. We paused to have lunch along the waterfront after our bus tour of the island. When we walked to the lift, the line was not too long. There are 2 lifts, cost (not remembering 100%) about 6 euros. Glad we waited, as the line moves quickly.

title: Colorful fishing village
text: In spite of the rain, we enjoyed our visit to this fishing village. The colorful boats and open air market make it worth a stop. This was a stop on our bus tour of Malta - 45 minutes was plenty of time to spend here.

title: Closed on Sunday
text: We got to see the beautiful exterior - an integral part of the city of Valletta. This is a co-cathedral because it shares duties with St Paul's Co-Cathedral in Mdina.

title: Lovely with great views of the harbor
text: Take the lift up to this lovely spot. Flowers blooming in October! Although not a particularly large area, it leads directly into the city of Valletta.

title: Beautiful
text:
A walled city dating back to 700BC, and the capital of Malta until the mid-1500's.
We had a quick stop here on a bus tour of the island. We would have liked to have had an hour to explore.

title: Stunning!
text: Church of the 3 Bells - worth the walk or visit because the view is amazing! This is one of the most photographed churches on Santorini! Our cruise ship was the only ship in port the day we were there and it happened to be in perfect position when we took our perfect picture!

title: Best Greek food!
text: We loved this restaurant! It is right along the trail from Fira. We sat upstairs and had an amazing view! We ordered chef's selections - and I had specific items I wanted to try! Greek salad with delicious vinaigrette, Fava - fava beans pureed with onion and olive oil, Domatokeftedes - fried tomato balls native to Santorini, served with warm, fresh pita! One of the best meals of our trip!

title: Main square in Oia
text: Beautiful! The main square is a great spot to meet. Close to the famous blue domed churches and shops.

title: Walked from Fira to Firastefani
text: My intent was to walk from Fira to Imerovigli. We had taken a bus to enjoy Oia, so when we returned to Fira, we began our walk. It was almost 80 degrees, and we are age 70. The trail is uphill all the way with uneven stones. We had proper walking shoes. We arrived in Firastefani after a 15-minute walk. We were ready for lunch and found a wonderful restaurant right on the trail, Mama Thira. The famous Church of the 3 Bells was around the corner from the restaurant. When we learned that it was another 30 minutes to walk to Imerovigli, (our day to see Santorini started at 7:30am!) we decided to walk back to Fira. So glad we walked part of the trail!

title: Beautiful!!
text: Amazing views of the blue-domed churches, the sea, shops - could have stayed longer! We arrived on a cruise ship (only ship in port that day), and chose an excursion that took us by bus - 45-minute drive to Oia from Fira - to Oia with free time on our own.

title: Small inland village
text: We were on a tour that took us by bus to this inland village of Ano Mera, known for the 16th century monastery and church, Panagia Tourliani and its marble bell tower. We had some Greek appetizers (keftedes, dolmades, fava, and Greek cheese on crostini) at a restaurant in the small town square, right in front of the monastery.

title: Historical
text: Panagia Paraportiani consists of 5 churches that have been built on top of or next to each other, beginning in the 14th century.

title: Take some time to enjoy this area!
text: Loved the winding "streets"...shops, beautiful bougainvillea still in bloom in October, brightly painted doors and balconies!

title: Picturesque!
text: Little Venice encompasses hones built in the 18th century, with balconies overhanging the sea. This was a stop on our cruise, and since we chose to travel at an "off" time, we were the only ship in port. Windy day, temperatures around 68-70 degrees - perfect time for us to enjoy this island!

title: Iconic symbol of the island of Mykonos
text: This was a stop on our cruise. It was not overly crowded. Very windy day! These windmills were built in the 16th century to mill grain into wheat. They are no longer in use, and are now a symbol of the island. So glad to be able to see them and take some great pictures!

title: Stunning
text: This ancient Greek temple was built to honor Athena and Poseidon. Caryatids and Ionic columns support the roof. Another beautiful temple that makes the climb to the Acropolis worth it!

title: Loved Anafiotika!
text: I had read about this group of island-like houses and it was a highlight for me to not only find it but explore this small area of only about 45 homes. Part of the Plaka neighborhood set at the "back" side of the Acropolis, it is picturesque! Built in the 18th century by workers from the island of Anafi, there are small, narrow walkways, steep steps, and worth the climb to the top for a beautiful view of Lycabettus Hill, one of the highest points in Athens!

title: Great area to explore and have lunch!
text: Part of our tour was 3 hours on our own, and we were dropped off in Plaka! So many shops and restaurants - perfect area to roam. We wanted to have authentic Greek food, and our lunch didn't disappoint: moussaka and souvlaka . I also wanted to visit Anafiotika - this group of island-like small houses - which we found and enjoyed! We loved Plaka! October was perfect weather, sunny and high 70's.

title: Amazing!
text: This is breathtaking, such history and well worth the climb to the top! This is why we came to Athens!

title: Most impressive sight in Athens!
text: The Acropolis is what I dreamed about seeing! We visited this while on a tour, so didn't have to wait in line to buy tickets. It's about 200 steps to the top - not a completely steep climb, but continuing up the path to the entrance. We arrived shortly after it was open, around 9:30. Lots of people, but not overly crowded. Loved being here in October! Weather was perfect, sunny and high 70's.

title: Beautiful facade!
text: Located in Piazza dei Cavalieri, this amazing palazzo was a school for the Knights of the Order of St Stephen and now a part of the university. The facade of the building is a technique of etching a pattern before the surface has dried, called sgraffito. Worth the walk down from the Leaning Tower, only about 5-7 minutes

title: Lovely piazza, Piazza dei Cavalieri
text: Only a 5-6 minute walk from the Leaning Tower, this lovely, quiet Piazza is historical. Once a political center, it became headquarters of the Order of the Knights of St Stephen, and now an educational center for the university.

title: Fascinating building!
text: We were in Pisa on a land tour, so we had limited time. But I had read about this building and Piazza, and wanted to see something of the town. We walked down from the Leaning Tower, only a short 5-6 minute walk. Two medieval towers, joined together by a clock tower, now is a library for the university.

title: Wonderful dinner!
text: This restaurant was referred by the Hotel Romanico Palace where we were staying. It was two blocks away from the hotel. Family run, using grandmother's recipes, I had veal with lemon and my husband had gnocchi with a blue cheese sauce - they melted in your mouth!! Great choice!

title: Highest medieval tower in Rome
text: This tower is also known as "Nero's Tower", as it is believed that Nero stood in the tower and watched the burning of the city. The second picture is taken from the top of the Vittorio Emanuele monument, and shows the tower behind Trajan Market. The towers aren't open, but I found them to be fascinating.

title: Torre dei Borgia
text: One of many medieval towers on our walk from the Colosseum to Piazza Venezia. This tower is best viewed from Piazza di San Pietro in Vincoli.

title: Medieval tower in Rome
text: Located about a block from the Colosseum, it is visible from the street. Not much to see, but amazing that this tower built in 1204 remains.

title: Wonderful gelato!
text: This is located in Piazza di Sant' Eustachio. It is directly across from the acclaimed Cafe. It was the middle of the afternoon, so we didn't want espresso. I had read great reviews and Punto Gelato did not disappoint! From chocolate with blue cheese and pine cone gelato, you will find unusual flavors! We went with more conventional ones: chocolate, salted caramel, and lemon. So good! Located around the corner from Piazza Navona, about a block from the Pantheon.

title: Four beautiful fountains!
text: We were on a quest to see some of Rome's unique fountains. Leaving the Spanish Steps on Via Sistina, about 5 minutes brings you to Piazza Barberini. Continue another block or two, and you will find yourself at an intersection with four amazing Bernini fountains, one at each corner!

title: Must see the inside of this church!
text: The beautiful ceiling is breathtaking! This church is behind the Pantheon, and there is an obelisk in front of the church with a beautiful elephant sculpture by Bernini. Take a few minutes to walk behind the Pantheon - it's one of my favorites in Rome!

title: Beautiful hotel
text: We stayed here two nights while on a land tour. The hotel is lovely, and decor very Roman. Our room was beautiful and clean. The walls are not well insulated, as we could here talking in the room above us. However, our breakfasts were delicious, and the location was perfect for us. We went on our own the day we arrived and were able to walk to the Spanish Steps in about 10 minutes. We were able to see other nearby sites, Piazza del Popolo and Piazza Barberini. The hotel clerk was helpful in recommending a wonderful restaurant for dinner one evening, one of our best dinners in Italy. Very nice!!

title: Loved this fountain!
text: The Fountain of the Turtles is located in Piazza Mattei. It was about a 10-15 minute walk from Piazza Venezia. We were on a quest to see some of the unique fountains of Rome, and were glad we walked here! There's a charming restaurant in the Piazza, where we had amazing homemade ravioli filled with cheese and spinach, and delicious asparagus crepes! Small and picturesque Piazza for a wonderful fountain!

title: Beautiful church with Michelangelo sculpture
text: Worth the short walk from the Colosseum! Located in Piazza di San Pietro in Vincoli (St Peter in Chains). You turn into what seems like an alley to reach this Piazza. The inside of the church is lovely, and the sculpture of Moses is amazing! You can also see the chains that once held St Peter.
